name: ccm
info: This self-report questionnaire asks for the current musical activities of the pupils. 8 binary items assess different musical activities (e. g. playing and instrument or making music in an ensemble). In addition, two 7-point rating scale items assess the intensity of recent musical activities.
reference: Muellensiefen, D., Harrison, P., Caprini, F., & Fancourt, A. (2015). Investigating the importance of self-theories of intelligence and musicality for students' academic and musical achievement. Frontiers in Psychology, 6, 1702. https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2015.01702

name: dac
info: This questionnaire investigates quantitatively the drama activities of the pupils (theatre, improvisation, role playing) within the last three months.
reference: Adaptation of The Physical Activity Questionnaire for Older Children (PAQ-C) and Adolescents (PAQ-A) by Kowalski, Crocker & Donen (2004), see PAC

name: deg
info: The demographic questions collect the age, gender, nationality, country of origin, mother tongue, and any other languages spoken in the family. Furthermore, a question asks for hearing impairments.

name: gms
info: The Gold-MSI is a questionnaire to record musical sophistication. It consists of 39 self-report items about musical abilities, skills and music-related behaviour. It has a hierarchical scale structure and comprises one general factor and five group factors: Active musical engagement, perceptual abilities, musical training, singing abilities, and handling of musical emotions.
reference: Muellensiefen, D., Gingras, B., Musil, J., & Stewart, L. (2014). The musicality of non-musicians: An index for assessing musical sophistication in the general population. PloS One, 9, e89642. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0089642

name: gms
info: 18 items were used for a general musical sophistication index. These 18 items were drawn from all five subscales but there was a clear preponderance of items from the Musical Training and the Singing Abilities subscales.

name: gms
info: Active engagement covers a range of active musical engagement behaviours (e.g. 'I keep track of new music that I come across', 'I often read or search the internet for things related to music') as well as the deliberate allocation of time and money on musical activities (e.g. 'I don't spend much of my disposable income on music', 'I listen attentively to music for _ hours per day').

name: gms
info: Emotions is associated with different and mainly active behaviours related to emotional responses to music (e.g. 'I am able to talk about the emotions that a piece of music evokes in me', 'I sometimes choose music that can trigger shivers down my spine').

name: gms
info: Musical training combines questions about the extent of musical training and practice (e.g. 'I engaged in regular daily practice of a musical instrument including voice for __ years', 'At the peak of my interest I practised on my primary instrument including voice for __ hours per day'), and about the degree of self-assessed musicianship ('I would not consider myself a musician', 'I have never been complimented for my talents as a musical performer').

name: gms
info: Perceptual abilities represents the self-assessment of a cognitive musical ability, and most of them related to music listening skills (e.g. 'I can compare and discuss differences between two performances or versions of a musical piece', 'I can tell when people sing or play out of tune').

name: gms
info: Singing abilities consists of seven items that reflected different skills and activities related to singing (e.g. 'After hearing a new song two or three times I can usually sing it by myself', 'I am not able to sing in harmony when somebody is singing a familiar tune').

name: gms
info: The Gold-MSI is a questionnaire to record musical sophistication. It consists of 39 self-report items about musical abilities, skills and music-related behaviour. It has a hierarchical scale structure and comprises one general factor and five group factors: Active musical engagement, perceptual abilities, musical training, singing abilities, and handling of musical emotions.
reference: Schaal, N., Bauer, A.-K., & Muellensiefen, D. (2014). Der Gold-MSI: Replikation und Validierung eines Fragebogeninstrumentes zur Messung Musikalischer Erfahrenheit anhand einer deutschen Stichprobe. [The Gold-MSI: Replication and validation of a survey instrument for measuring musical sophistication with a German sample.]ÊMusicae Scientiae, 18(4), 423-447. DOI:10.1177/1029864914541851.

name: gms
info: 18 items were used for a general musical sophistication index. These 18 items were drawn from all five subscales but there was a clear preponderance of items from the Musical Training and the Singing Abilities subscales.

name: gms
info: Active engagement covers a range of active musical engagement behaviours (e.g. 'I keep track of new music that I come across', 'I often read or search the internet for things related to music') as well as the deliberate allocation of time and money on musical activities (e.g. 'I don't spend much of my disposable income on music', 'I listen attentively to music for _ hours per day').

name: gms
info: Emotions is associated with different and mainly active behaviours related to emotional responses to music (e.g. 'I am able to talk about the emotions that a piece of music evokes in me', 'I sometimes choose music that can trigger shivers down my spine').

name: gms
info: Musical training combines questions about the extent of musical training and practice (e.g. 'I engaged in regular daily practice of a musical instrument including voice for __ years', 'At the peak of my interest I practised on my primary instrument including voice for __ hours per day'), and about the degree of self-assessed musicianship ('I would not consider myself a musician', 'I have never been complimented for my talents as a musical performer').

name: gms
info: Perceptual abilities represents the self-assessment of a cognitive musical ability, and most of them related to music listening skills (e.g. 'I can compare and discuss differences between two performances or versions of a musical piece', 'I can tell when people sing or play out of tune').

name: gms
info: Singing abilities consists of seven items that reflected different skills and activities related to singing (e.g. 'After hearing a new song two or three times I can usually sing it by myself', 'I am not able to sing in harmony when somebody is singing a familiar tune').

name: lie
info: The scale captures the tendency to describe oneself with socially desirable attributes.
reference: Carifio, J. (1994). Sensitive data and students' tendencies to give socially desirable responses. Journal of Alcohol and Drug Education, 39, 74Ð84.

name: mhe
info: This questionnaire records the degree of musical activities within the home environment of the pupils as well as the parental support for musical and school activities.
response_format: 2 items with binary checkboxes and 5 items with a 4-point ratings scale
reference: Muellensiefen, D., Harrison, P., Caprini, F., & Fancourt, A. (2015). Investigating the importance of self-theories of intelligence and musicality for students' academic and musical achievement. Frontiers in Psychology, 6, 1702. https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2015.01702

name: pac
name_full: Physical Activity Questionnaire for Older Children
info: The PAQ-C collects the amount of sporting and physical activities using 5 items. It records quantitative data (frequency instead of intensity of the activities) concerning the last 3 months. We use the version for children (approx. 14-20 years).
reference: Kowalski, K. C., Crocker, P. R. E., & Donen, R. M. (2004). The Physical Activity Questionnaire for older children (PAQ-C) and adolescents (PAQ-A) manual. College of Kinesiology, University of Saskatchewan, Canada.
reference_2: Kowalski, K. C., Crocker, P. R.E., & Kowalski, N. P. (1997). Convergent validity of the physical activity questionnaire for adolescents. Pediatric Exercise Science, 9, 342Ð352. https://doi.org/10.1123/pes.9.4.342

name: sca
info: The SCA questionnaire records the individual attitudes towards learning in general as well as the attitudes and estimation regarding the own school and class context. It consists of 25 items. A short version of the SCA comprising only 3 items has also been developed.
reference: Bracken, B. A. (1992). Multidimensional Self Concept Scale. Austin, TX: Pro-ed.

name: scs
info: The self-concept scale by Bracken (1992) has been developed for children and adolescents (9-19 years old). It consists of 25 items and asks adolescents to evaluate their own behaviour patterns, personality traits and social integration e. g. within the peer group.
reference: Bracken, B. A. (1992). Multidimensional Self Concept Scale. Austin, TX: Pro-ed.

name: sdq
info: The SDQ is a short questionnaire about behavioural difficulties and strengths in children and adolescents. Versions for parents and teachers as well as self-report are available - we use the self-report version. Specific care was taken to achieve a balance of positive and negative behavioural aspects across the 25 SDQ items. The 25 items form 5 scales (conduct problems, hyperactivity, emotional symptoms, peer-related problems and prosocial behaviour) with 5 items each. The scores for hyperactivity, emotional symptoms, conduct problems and peer problems can be summed to generate a total difficulties score ranging from 0 to 40; the prosocial score is not incorporated in the reverse direction into ttotal difficulties score since the absence of prosocial behaviours is conceptually different.
reference: Goodman, R., Meltzer, H., & Bailey, V. (1998). The strengths and difficulties questionnaire: A pilot study on the validity of the self-report version. European Child & Adolescent Psychiatry, 7, 125Ð130. https://doi.org/10.1007/s007870050057

name: sdq
info: I am restless, I cannot stay still for long'; 'I am constantly fidgeting or squirming'; 'I am easily distracted, I find it difficult to concentrate'; 'I think before I do things'; and 'I finish the work I'm doing. My attention is good'.

name: sdq
info: I get a lot of headaches, stomach-aches or sickness'; 'I worry a lot'; 'I am often unhappy, down-hearted or tearful'; 'I am nervous in new situations. I easily lose confidence'; and 'I have many fears. I am easily scared'.

name: sdq
info: I get very angry and often lose my temper'; 'I usually do as I am told'; 'I fight a lot. I can make other people do what I want'; 'I am often accused of lying or cheating'; and 'I take things that are not mine from home, school or elsewhere'.

name: sdq
info: I am usually on my own. I generally play alone or keep to myself'; 'I have one good friend or more'; 'Other people my age generally like me'; 'Other children or young people pick on me or bully me'; and 'I get on better with adults than with people my own age'.

name: sdq
info: I try to be nice to other people. I care about their feelings'; 'I usually share with others (food, games, pens, etc.)'; 'I am helpful if someone is hurt, upset or feeling ill'; 'I am kind to younger children'; and 'I often volunteer to help others (parents, teachers, children)'.

name: sem
info: This questionnaire assesses commitment and attitudes of pupils towards their school. The scale consists of 23 items and includes questions about behaviour, emotion and cognition. The instrument has a hierarchical subscale structure and comprises 3 subscales with two corresponding subscales: Behavioural Engageent: Attentiveness, School Compliance; Emotional Engagement: School belonging, Valuing of School Education; Cognitive Engagement: Self-regulated Learning, Cognitive Strategy Use.
reference: Wang, M.-T., Willett, J. B., & Eccles, J. S. (2011). The assessment of school engagement: Examining dimensionality and measurement invariance by gender and race/ethnicity. Journal of School Psychology, 49, 465Ð480. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jsp.2011.04.001

name: sem
info: The construct of behavioral engagement was measured by two sets of factors: items from the Attentiveness subscale and items from the School Compliance subscale.

name: sem
info: The three-item subscale Attentiveness measures the extent to which students report being distracted in classes and have trouble getting schoolwork done. A sample item is 'How often do you have trouble paying attention in classes?'

name: sem
info: The five-item scale School Compliance describes the levels to which students engage in misconduct in school. A sample item is 'How often have you skipped classes?'

name: sem
info: Two factors were included to represent the construct of emotional engagement: the School Belonging scale and the Valuing of School Education scale.

name: sem
info: The three-item scale School Belonging represents the extent to which adolescents feel personally accepted, respected, and supported by adults and peers in school. A sample item is 'In general, I feel like a real part in this school.'

name: sem
info: The six-item scale Valuing of School Education assesses adolescents' interest and belief in the importance and relevance of the general goals of education and academic achievement espoused by the school. A sample item is 'I have to do well in school if I want to be a success in life.'

name: sem
info: Two factors were included to represent the construct of cognitive engagement: the Self-Regulated Learning scale and the Cognitive Strategy Use scale.

name: sem
info: The four-item scale Self-Regulated Learning represents adolescents' perceived ability of self-monitoring and evaluation. A sample item is 'How often are you very good at carrying out the plans you make for solving problems?'

name: sem
info: The four-item scale Cognitive Strategy uses measures adolescents' perceived use of strategic approach to learning. A sample item is 'How often do you try to relate what you are studying to other things you know about?'

name: ses
info: The socio-economic status of the pupils is recorded using 6 items. The questionnaire asks for the educational level of the parents and the professional activity of the main income earner (highest wage).
response_format: 2 items with 7-point rating scale (educational level) and 4 categorical items
reference: Rose, D. (2005). The ESeC class schema summarized. Retrieved from https://www.iser.essex.ac.uk/archives/esec/validation-process
reference_2: Rose, D., & Pevalin, D. J. (2001). The national statistics socio-economic classification: Unifying official and sociological approaches to the conceptualisation and measurement of social class (ISER Working Papers No. 2001-4). Colchester: University of Essex.

name: ses
info: This subscale asks for the professional activities of the parents.

name: ses
info: This subscale asks for the educational level of the parents.

name: sos
info: The Student Opinion Scale is a means to measure and control for the motivation of the participants concerning the answering of questionnaires and tests. It is a validated self-report questionnaire.
reference: Sundre, D. L., & Moore, D. L. (2002). The student opinion scale: A measure of examinee motivation. Assessment Update, 14, 8Ð9.

name: sos
info: A score of 25 on the Effort subscale means that the student perceived that they fully engaged in effortful behavior on the test (or tests).

name: sos
info: A score of 25 on the Importance subscale means that the student thought it important to do well on the test or tests. Low scores obviously mean that the student put forth less effort or perceived doing well to be of less importance.

name: toi
info: The seven-item TOI questionnaire asks for attitudes of individuals regarding intelligence. The central question is whether the pupils regard intelligence as something static and unchangeable (entity view) or as something fluid and changeable (incremental view).
response_format: 1 binary item and 6 items with a 6-point rating scale
reference: Dweck, C. S. (2000). Self-theories: Their role in motivation, personality, and development. Essays in social psychology. Philadelphia, PA: Psychology Press.

name: tom
info: The TOM questionnaire consists of 12 items. It is asking for attitudes about musical abilities (acquired or innate), but it is modelled after the Conception of the Nature of Athletic Ability Questionnaire - Version 2 (CNAAQ-2) by Biddle et al. (2003) and has a hierarchical scale structure: Gift, Improvement, Learning, Stable, Incremental, Entity.
response_format: 1 binary item and 6 items with a 6-point rating scale
reference: Muellensiefen, D., Harrison, P., Caprini, F., & Fancourt, A. (2015). Investigating the importance of self-theories of intelligence and musicality for students' academic and musical achievement. Frontiers in Psychology, 6, 1702. https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2015.01702
reference_2: Modelled after: Biddle, S. J. H., Wang, C. K. J., Chatzisarantis, N. L. D., & Spray, C. M. (2003). Motivation for physical activity in young people: entity and incremental beliefs about athletic ability. Journal of Sports Sciences, 21, 973Ð989. https://doi.org/10.1080/02640410310001641377

name: tip
info: The TIPI measures personality on the big five personality dimensions (openness, agreeableness, extraversion, conscientiousness and neuroticism) using 2 items for each dimension.
reference: Gosling, S. D., Rentfrow, P. J., & Swann, W. B. (2003). A very brief measure of the Big-Five personality domains. Journal of Research in Personality, 37, 504Ð528. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0092-6566(03)00046-1

name: bat
info: The BAT records the ability of the students to recognize and evaluate a beat within a short music excerpt. Each music excerpt (Jazz, Rock or orchestral Pop) is played twice with added beep tones. The pupils have to decide in which version of the excerpt the beep tones are off the beat of the music.
reference: Harrison, P. M. C., & Muellensiefen, D. (2018). Development and Validation of the Computerised Adaptive Beat Alignment Test (CA-BAT). Scientific Reports, 8, 12395. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-018-30318-8

name: edt
info: The Emotion Discrimination Test measures the ability to discriminate emotions expressed in music. Participants listen to two versions of the same short melody and have to decide which one expresses a given emotional quality better.
reference: MacGregor, C. L., & Mullensiefen, D. (2019). The Musical Emotion Discrimination Task: A New Measure for Assessing the Ability to Discriminate Emotions in Music. Frontiers in Psychology, 10, 1955.

name: jaj
info: This test measures the capacity of the visuo-spatial working memory using a dual-task paradigm. Pupils have to choose for each item whether two cartoon figures hold blue balls in the same or different hands and also remember the positions of the balls. After each set of pictures the test asks to recall the positions of the balls in the correct order.
reference: Alloway, T. P. (2007). Automated Working Memory Assessment (AWMA). London: Harcourt.

name: mdt
info: This melody discrimination test measures the ability to discriminate similar but slightly altered melodies from each other. Each item consists of three versions of the same melody. The three versions are in different keys and, additionally, in one of the versions a few notes have been changed. The task is to name the version with the altered notes.
reference: Harrison, P. M. C., Collins, T., & Muellensiefen, D. (2017). Applying modern psychometric techniques to melodic discrimination testing: Item response theory, computerised adaptive testing, and automatic item generation. Scientific Reports, 7, 425. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-017-03586-z

name: miq
info: The MIQ assesses fluid intelligence, non-verbal reasoning and abstract problem solving abilities. The pupils look at a visual puzzle and have to fill in the missing puzzle piece. They have to select their answer out of 8 given answering options within 120 seconds.
reference: Chan, Y. W. F., & Kosinski, M. (2015). ICAR Project Wiki. International Cognitive Ability Resource (ICAR). Retrieved from http://icar-project.com/projects/icar-project/wiki

name: mps
info: This is a listening test that captures musical preferences for each of the five factor of the MUSIC model (Rentfrow, Goldberg, & Levitin, 2011). A 15s excerpt from each of 25 unpublished tracks (5 for each factor) is rated on a 5-point rating scale that asks for liking of the track.
reference: Rentfrow, P. J., Goldberg, L. R., & Levitin, D. J. (2011). The structure of musical preferences: a five-factor model. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 100, 1139Ð1157. https://doi.org/10.1037/a0022406

name: mpt
info: The MTP measures the ability to recognize if the pitch of the singing voice sounds right or wrong in relation to the background music. Each music excerpt is played twice and in one of the examples the pitch level of the singing voice has been moved up or down. The task is to identify this wrong-sounding version.
reference: Larrouy-Maestri, P., Harrison, P. M., & Muellensiefen, D. (2019). The mistuning perception test: A new measurement instrument.ÊBehavior Research Methods,Ê51(2), 663-675.

name: rat
info: The rhythm test measures the ability to process and remember short musical rhythms with 4, 8 or 16 events. Participants listen to the rhythm and then have to select the one of four graphical representations that corresponds to the structure of the rhythm.
reference: Zuk, J., Andrade, P. E., Andrade, O. V. C. A., Gardiner, M., & Gaab, N. (2013). Musical, language, and reading abilities in early Portuguese readers. Frontiers in Psychology, 4, 288. https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2013.00288

name: sss
info: The sound similarity test assesses the ability to make comparative judgments about very short (800 ms) music excerpts. The test requires participants to sort 16 short clips into 4 groups according to their perceived similarity.
reference: Musil, J., El-Nusairi, B., & Muellensiefen, D. (2013). Perceptual dimensions of short audio clips and corresponding timbre features. In M. Aramaki, M. Barthet, R. Kronland-Martinet, & S. Ystad (Eds.), LNCS sublibrary. SL 3, Information systems and application, incl. Internet/Web and HCI: Vol. 7900. From sounds to music and emotions: 9th international symposium, CMMR 2012, London, UK, June 19-22, 2012 : revised selected papers (pp.Ê214Ð227). Berlin: Springer.
reference_2: Siedenburg, K., & Muellensiefen, D. (2017). Modeling timbre similarity of short music clips.ÊFrontiers in Psychology,Ê8, 639.

name: pit
info: The ability to silently hear music in the mind has been argued to be fundamental to musicality. Objective measurements of this subjective imagery experience are needed if this link between imagery ability and musicality is to be investigated. However, previous tests of musical imagery either rely on self-report, rely on melodic memory, or do not cater in range of abilities. The Pitch Imagery Arrow Task (PIAT) was designed to address these shortcomings.
reference: Gelding, R., Harrison, P., Silas, S., Johnson, B., Thompson, W., & Muellensiefen, D. (2020). An efficient and adaptive test of auditory mental imagery.ÊPsychological Research.

name: bds
name_full: Backward Digit Span Working Memory Test
info: BDS tasks represent a classic measure of WM (Case & Globerson, 1974), requiring participants to remember a sequence of digits, mentally reverse the sequence, and enter the reversed sequence. Because this BDS task required responding by clicking the numbers on a keypad, it had a particular visuospatial quality to it compared to other BDS tasks.
